Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Feature]: add dotnet nuget why to dotnet CLI" (#11943) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

This is a tracking issue for feature request https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11782

Design spec - [dotnet nuget why command](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/blob/dev/accepted/2022/dotnet-nuget-why-proposal.md) ([Spec PR](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/11875))

Proof of concept: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/tree/pragnya17-dotnet-nuget-why ([compare](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/compare/dev...pragnya17-dotnet-nuget-why))

### Additional Context and Details

- [ ] Add `dotnet nuget why` command - https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/2862
- [ ] Add docs to `dotnet/docs` - https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13499
- [ ] Add integration to `dotnet/sdk` - https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/2861

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet IntelliCode Package Suggestions are missing Author in packages list" (#13515) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

17.11

### Worked before?

N/A

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

As part of the new feature for Known Owner rendering in PM UI, https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/5766, the IntelliSense Suggested packages (indicated with a `*` in the packages list) now attempt to read an `Owner` property from their metadata in order to render Known Owner profile hyperlinks. 

Since author is never shown as the feed supports Known Owner, these suggested packages now always show a blank instead of "by author" beside their package ID.

The owner metadata is not available from IntelliSense, so there will never be a hyperlink to show.
In some cases, author is being shown as a hyperlink, which is incorrect. 

I've updated the spec for the feature in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/13514 to clarify that author will be shown for IntelliSense suggested packages

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Update Owner Author spec to indicate author is always shown" (#13514) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: The implementation as of now will be that Recommended packages will never shown Known Owner, so reflect this in the spec.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGetPackageRoot and other Pkg_* variables from GeneratePathProperty only present after first 'dotnet restore'" (#13513) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

8.0.301

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Context

We have a task that runs after `dotnet restore` to handle some post-processing. To address it, we use `GeneratePathProperty` so we are able to use its path in `UsingTask` regardless of where it is installed. However, the first time we restore the project, we always get an error because the variable expands to an empty value.

This doesn't appear to be related to `GeneratePathProperty` because `NuGetPackageRoot` is also empty during that run.

#### Reproduction Steps

1. Create `NuGetErrorCase.csproj`:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
    <PropertyGroup>
        <TargetFramework>netstandard2.1</TargetFramework>
    </PropertyGroup>

    <ItemGroup>
        <PackageReference Include="YUICompressor.NET.MSBuild" Version="3.0.0" GeneratePathProperty="true" />
    </ItemGroup>

    <Target Name="DoTest" AfterTargets="Restore">
        <Message Text="Package path = '$(PkgYUICompressor_NET_MSBuild)'..." Importance="high" />
        <Message Text="NuGetPackageRoot = '$(NuGetPackageRoot)'..." Importance="high" />
    </Target>
</Project>
```

2. Run `dotnet restore`, output:

```
  Determining projects to restore...
  Restored /home/werk/Downloads/nuget-case/NuGetErrorCase.csproj (in 172 ms).
  Package path = ''...
  NuGetPackageRoot = ''...
```

3. Run `dotnet restore` again, output:

```           
  Determining projects to restore...
  All projects are up-to-date for restore.
  Package path = '/home/werk/.nuget/packages/yuicompressor.net.msbuild/3.0.0'...
  NuGetPackageRoot = '/home/werk/.nuget/packages/'...
```

To reproduce again just remove `bin` and `obj` and the problem returns.

This sounds similar to #9150, but we're not using MSBuild directly and using only using `dotnet restore`. We're not sure about how this is handled internally, but variables magically appearing from the second restore is very non-obvious to us. The workaround we have been using up until now is 'just run twice', but as you can imagine it's not a great workaround :sweat_smile: .

#### Additional Flatpak .NET 8 Weirdness

There is further weirdness occurring with these variables since the above is what happens for me on Arch Linux using .NET 8 from the native repositories (`dotnet-sdk` package), and also happens on Windows 11. However, if I run the above steps with [sandboxed Flatpak .NET 8](https://github.com/flathub/org.freedesktop.Sdk.Extension.dotnet8) from `org.freedesktop.Sdk.Extension.dotnet8`, the variables are never filled in and step 2 is all that happens. How is this possible? Is there some kind of .NET SDK extension that is needed for these variables to be filled in?

This might be a different problem specific to the Flatpak, though, but I'm not sure how to 'debug' it to know whether I should report it here or to the Flatpak extension repository.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGetPackageRoot and other Pkg_* variables from GeneratePathProperty only present after first 'dotnet restore'" (#13513) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

8.0.301

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

## Context

We have a task that runs after `dotnet restore` to handle some post-processing. To address it, we use `GeneratePathProperty` so we are able to use its path in `UsingTask` regardless of where it is installed. However, the first time we restore the project, we always get an error because the variable expands to an empty value.

This doesn't appear to be related to `GeneratePathProperty` because `NuGetPackageRoot` is also empty during that run.

## Reproduction Steps

1. Create `NuGetErrorCase.csproj`:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
    <PropertyGroup>
        <TargetFramework>netstandard2.1</TargetFramework>
    </PropertyGroup>

    <ItemGroup>
        <PackageReference Include="YUICompressor.NET.MSBuild" Version="3.0.0" GeneratePathProperty="true" />
    </ItemGroup>

    <Target Name="DoTest" AfterTargets="Restore">
        <Message Text="Package path = '$(PkgYUICompressor_NET_MSBuild)'..." Importance="high" />
        <Message Text="NuGetPackageRoot = '$(NuGetPackageRoot)'..." Importance="high" />
    </Target>
</Project>
```

2. Run `dotnet restore`, output:

```
  Determining projects to restore...
  Restored /home/werk/Downloads/nuget-case/NuGetErrorCase.csproj (in 172 ms).
  Package path = ''...
  NuGetPackageRoot = ''...
```

3. Run `dotnet restore` again, output:

```           
  Determining projects to restore...
  All projects are up-to-date for restore.
  Package path = '/home/werk/.nuget/packages/yuicompressor.net.msbuild/3.0.0'...
  NuGetPackageRoot = '/home/werk/.nuget/packages/'...
```

To reproduce again just remove `bin` and `obj` and the problem returns.

This sounds similar to #9150, but we're not using MSBuild directly and using only using `dotnet restore`. We're not sure about how this is handled internally, but variables magically appearing from the second restore is very non-obvious to us. The workaround we have been using up until now is 'just run twice', but as you can imagine it's not a great workaround :sweat_smile: .

## Additional Flatpak .NET 8 Weirdness

There is further weirdness occurring with these variables since the above is what happens for me on Arch Linux using .NET 8 from the native repositories (`dotnet-sdk` package), and also happens for colleagues on Windows. However, if I run the above steps with sandboxed Flatpak .NET 8 from `org.freedesktop.Sdk.Extension.dotnet8`, the variables are never filled in and step 2 is all that happens. How is this possible? Is there some kind of .NET SDK extension that is needed for these variables to be filled in?

This might be a different problem specific to the Flatpak, though, but I'm not sure how to 'debug' it to know whether I should report it here or to the Flatpak extension repository.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
In `NuGetErrorCase.csproj`


<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
    <PropertyGroup>
        <TargetFramework>netstandard2.1</TargetFramework>
    </PropertyGroup>

    <ItemGroup>
        <PackageReference Include="YUICompressor.NET.MSBuild" Version="3.0.0" GeneratePathProperty="true" />
    </ItemGroup>

    <Target Name="DoTest" AfterTargets="Restore">
        <Message Text="Package path = '$(PkgYUICompressor_NET_MSBuild)'..." Importance="high" />
        <Message Text="NuGetPackageRoot = '$(NuGetPackageRoot)'..." Importance="high" />
    </Target>
</Project>
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet restore/Visual Studio conflicting with .esproj + Nx project.json" (#13512) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Visual Studio 17.10.1, dotnet 8.0.300

### Worked before?

Visual Studio 17.9.1

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Steps:
1. Create a solution containing a .esproj project.
2. Inside that .esproj project, initialize an Nx Workspace in the root. It might even break if you put just a file called project.json - should be in the same directory as your .esproj.
3. Try running dotnet restore against the sln containing the .esproj

Context: 
I'm using an .esproj that contains an Nx project. The Nx project adds a project.json file which NuGet appears to be trying to process now - previously it was ignored.

I've had limited success in the command line by forcing `<RestoreProjectStyle>Unknown</RestoreProjectStyle>` in the .esproj, but it doesn't appear to be respected by Visual Studio's package management UI.

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Hello everyone, good morning.

I'm having issues with the build. My code is in Azure Repos, and I'm using App Center for the build. Locally, the code is working perfectly, and when I publish via Visual Studio to the Deployment Center, it also works perfectly. The problem lies in the CI process; when I commit to the master branch, the Deployment Center initiates synchronization to perform the build, and at this step, I'm encountering an exception.

Looking forward to hear from you.
Thanks in advance,

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Rebuilding in VS causes unnecessary restores" (#13505) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

VS internal preview

### Worked before?

Before https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/5819

### Impact

Other

### Repro Steps & Context

Firstly, the regression required you use a version of VS with this dotnet/project-system change: https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/pull/9470

Second, it might not have a user observable regression. It's a perf regression only.  If it's observable, then the timestamp on the project.assets.json file in the obj folder will change, even if the contents do not.

But the repro steps are to open a solution with SDK style projects, and then "rebuild" (not just "build) the solution. In NuGet.Commands.dll's RestoreCommand.CommitAsync, it will think the assets file has changed, but it should not have.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Building with `net8.0-ios` is picking `net8.0` from NuGet package instead of `net8.0-ios17.0`" (#13510) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

.NET SDK 8.0.300

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context


[themes-build-ios-winui.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/15551150/themes-build-ios-winui.zip)

See target `ResolvePackageAssets` for the build of `Uno.Themes.WinUI.Samples.Mobile.csproj`. Specifically, the output item `RuntimeCopyLocalItems` and more specifically the Uno.UI.dll path. It's `/Users/runner/.nuget/packages/uno.winui/5.3.0-dev.1669/lib/net8.0/Uno.UI.dll`.

This version of the Uno package has `net8.0-ios17.0`. But `net8.0` was favored over `net8.0-ios17.0`, which doesn't feel correct.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: add dotnet nuget why to dotnet CLI" (#11943) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

This is a tracking issue for feature request https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11782

Design spec - [dotnet nuget why command](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/blob/dev/accepted/2022/dotnet-nuget-why-proposal.md) ([Spec PR](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/11875))

Proof of concept: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/tree/pragnya17-dotnet-nuget-why ([compare](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/compare/dev...pragnya17-dotnet-nuget-why))

### Additional Context and Details

- [ ] Add `dotnet nuget why` command - https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/2862
- [ ] Add docs to `dotnet/docs` - https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13499
- [ ] Add integration to `dotnet/sdk` - https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/2861

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enable package source mapping via msbuild properties" (#13507) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

MSBuild.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Per https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/msbuild-targets#restore-target I can define restoreSources to provide a list of packageSources.  But when I do so, I get an error at restore time:

error NU1507: There are 2 package sources defined in your configuration. When using central package management, please map your package sources with package source mapping (https://aka.ms/nuget-package-source-mapping) or specify a single package source.

I don't see any method of defining package source mapping as an msbuild property.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Pipeline changes are not clear about which release branch they apply to" (#13367) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
As someone who has recently had to cherry-pick multiple CI Pipeline changes to release branches, I can say it's time consuming and meticulous work to determine which parts of which commits ought to be cherry-picked.

Philosophies vary whether we need to update release branch pipelines frequently, but I would like this to become part of the conscious effort when writing a PR description.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as April 8th, 2024" (#72) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as April 8th, 2024. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by April 8th, 2024 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org that are signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-april-8th-2024/
